snippet: A study released by the Pew Research Center found that the number rose since 2000 after decades of decline, likely driven in part by economic factors and changing demographics.
abstract: Pew Research Center study shows that number of stay-at-home mothers in the United States has risen since 2000 after decades of decline; finds that 29 percent of mothers with children younger than 18, about 10.4 million women, stayed at home in 2012, compared with the historic low of 23 percent in 1999; change is likely driven in part by economic factors and changing demographics.
